stem: A 65-year-old client 2 days post-op from hip replacement surgery suddenly reports sharp chest pain and shortness of breath. Vital signs: HR 115, RR 26, BP 102/68, SpO2 88% on RA. Complete the bowtie to plan the immediate care.

rationale.correct: The client presents with classic risk factors (post-op, immobility) and symptoms (sudden SOB, chest pain, hypoxia) of PE. Immediate actions focus on oxygenation and preventing further clot propagation (Heparin). Monitoring focuses on respiratory stability.
rationale.incorrect: Furosemide is for heart failure/edema. Chest tube is for pneumothorax. While Troponin can rise in PE due to right heart strain, it is not the primary parameter to monitor for acute stability in this context.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking all chest pain is MI
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Look for the risk factors. Post-op immobility points strongly to VTE/PE.

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Pulmonary Embolism
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions are: Apply oxygen via non-rebreather mask; Initiate IV Heparin protocol. Monitor: Oxygen saturation (SpO2); Respiratory effort and breath sounds. Furosemide is for heart failure/edema. Chest tube is for pneumothorax. While Troponin can rise in PE due to right heart strain, it is not the primary parameter to monitor for acute stability in this context.
